awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Quantifying the effects of variable light and iron on the nitrate assimilation isotope effect of phytoplankton
awd_abstract_narration:
Phytoplankton are microscopic, single-celled organisms that play an important role in the Earth?s ecosystems, elemental cycles, and climate. These organisms, which live in surface ocean waters, require sunlight and nutrients to grow and reproduce. In the oceans around Antarctica, nitrate (NO3-) as a nutrient source of nitrogen (N) is usually abundant while the nutrient iron is often sparse. Light availability also changes from complete darkness to 24 hours of constant sunlight, as well as from low light deeper in the water column to high, stressful light at the ocean surface. As a consequence, the phytoplankton in the Southern Ocean often live in a suboptimal environment in which conditions for growth are frequently changing. Scientists understand that nutrient supply and light availability affect these organisms and that these organisms, in turn, can alter the chemical composition of the seawater. For example, nitrate can occur in different forms, including a lighter (14N) and heavier (15N) form of NO3-, depending on which stable isotope of N is present in the molecule. Phytoplankton prefer to use the lighter isotope during uptake and incorporation into biomass, though the ratio of 15N/14N used by phytoplankton has been shown to vary depending on environmental conditions. Notably, the isotope ratio used by phytoplankton is recorded in sediments and can be used to determine both the historic composition of ocean waters and the productivity of phytoplankton. This project will test the hypothesis that enhanced light and/or iron stress change the isotopic ratios of water column nitrate- in specific ways. A combination of laboratory culture and field experiments will be conducted. Cultures of important Southern Ocean phytoplankton species will be grown under environmentally-relevant light and iron conditions where ratio of 15N/14N used by phytoplankton, physiological changes, and molecular markers of iron and light stress and nitrate assimilation will be measured. Similar measurements will be done in shipboard experiments on a cruise in the Southern Ocean with South African colleagues. These data will increase our understanding of past and present productivity in the Southern Ocean, and how phytoplankton changed the chemical composition of the seawater. Undergraduates from underrepresented groups in the STEM field and graduate students from Florida State University and Old Dominion University as well as students from South Africa will collaborate on this project. The improved process understanding of the N isotope effect will be presented not only at scientific national and international conferences but also during local outreach events at local K12 schools.

Interpretation of both modern water column nitrate (NO3-) isotopic ratio (d15N) measurements generated by GEOTRACES and other cruises, as well as metrics of paleo-nutrient utilization, depend upon a mechanistic understanding of the degree to which NO3- assimilation by phytoplankton discriminates against the heavier isotope, 15NO3- (NO3- assimilation epsilon). We currently lack the ability to predict how iron and light stress impacts the NO3- assimilation epsilon. The proposed work will test the hypothesis that enhanced light and/or iron stress elevates the epsilon for NO3-assimilation. This hypothesis will be tested by a combination of laboratory culture work and field work on a cruise of opportunity in the Southern Ocean. Mesocosm experiments will include both increasing and alleviating light and/or iron stress on monoclonal phytoplankton cultures and in natural phytoplankton communities while measuring the response of the NO3- assimilation epsilon. Water column samples will be collected on the cruise for analysis of dissolved and size-fractionated particulate N concentration and d15N, as well as phytoplankton community composition, photophysiology and gene expression markers of iron and light stress and NO3- assimilation. In particular, the expression of iron and light stress markers will be used to evaluate the relative contribution of iron and light stress to field-based estimates of the NO3-- assimilation epsilon. The results from these field measurements, together with lab-based culture studies, will be used to constrain the range of the epsilon for NO3- assimilation under environmentally-relevant light and iron conditions, including the potential alleviation of iron stress as has been hypothesized to have occurred during the last glacial maximum (a.k.a. the Martin hypothesis).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Phytoplankton, the single-celled organisms at the base of the marine food web, play a vital role in Earth’s carbon cycle. Under favorable environmental conditions, they absorb large amounts of atmospheric CO₂ and transfer it to the deep ocean and thus play a well-recognized role in the regulation of climate over geological timescales. In nutrient-rich regions like the Southern Ocean, where nitrate (NO₃⁻) is abundant, the availability of light and iron (Fe) significantly influences phytoplankton growth. During growth, these organisms alter seawater chemistry by consuming nutrients such as nitrate, phosphate, and silica. During nitrate uptake, they preferentially assimilate the lighter nitrogen isotope (¹⁴N) over the heavier isotope (¹⁵N), leaving the remaining nitrate in the upper water column enriched in ¹⁵N. 

 This isotopic pattern serves as a valuable indicator of nutrient utilization efficiency, both in contemporary and ancient oceans, as the signal (known as a proxy) is recorded in their biomass. 

However, environmental conditions can modify the ratio of ¹⁴N to ¹⁵N assimilated, introducing uncertainties in the interpretation of the ¹⁵N isotope proxy.

In October and November 2019, fieldwork was conducted in the Southern Ocean through a collaboration with a South African university as part of the SCALE (Southern Ocean Seasonal Experiment) research expedition. he expedition departed from Cape Town, South Africa, traveling south toward the ice edge along the zero meridian (~50°S), then eastward through the ice to approximately 15°E, before returning along a similar transect. During the cruise, underway sampling of phytoplankton biomass, water column nitrate isotope ratios and environmental conditions here probed. During the cruise, underway sampling was conducted to measure phytoplankton biomass, nitrate isotope ratios in the water column, and environmental conditions. The data revealed a correlation between the depth of the mixed layer, average light intensity, and iron availability, all of which influenced the isotope effect during phytoplankton nitrate assimilation.

Three manipulative experiments were performed during the transect to investigate how light and iron availability affect isotope fractionation and phytoplankton productivity under controlled conditions. Native phytoplankton communities were acclimated to light intensities representing depths of 15 meters (shallow mixing) and 50 meters (deep mixing). Iron availability was manipulated in two ways: by adding small amounts of iron to enrich iron levels and by reducing iron availability using an iron-binding agent. A control treatment mimicking mid-mixed layer light conditions (~25 meters) without iron manipulation was also included. Two experiments were successfully completed: one near the Sub-Antarctic Front (SAF) and another in the Marginal Ice Zone (MIZ) close to the sea ice edge. A third experiment, conducted near the SAF during the return transect, was cut short due to time constraints as the vessel returned to port earlier than anticipated.

The results revealed co-limitation by iron and light in the Sub-Antarctic Front (SAF), while in the colder waters of the Marginal Ice Zone (MIZ), phytoplankton growth was primarily limited by iron, with minimal influence from light availability. Iotope analysis from the first experiment demonstrated the distinct effects of iron and light on nitrate isotope uptake (¹⁴N and ¹⁵N). The control treatment in the first experiment exhibited isotope fractionation patterns consistent with in situ observations of the sampled community. These manipulative experiments validated our hypothesis and aligned with in situ data, confirming that both iron limitation and light stress (at high and low intensities) altered nitrate fractionation during assimilation of nitrate. Our current understanding of the processes driving these changes in fractionation suggests that stressed organisms reallocate energy and resources to mitigate stress. This involves multiple metabolic functions, including energy dissipation through non-photosynthetic pathways such as heat release and fluorescence. More importantly, stressed phytoplankton channel energy into a process known as non-assimilatory nitrate uptake, which directly influences the isotope fractionation of the cells.

Complementary laboratory studies were conducted by two graduate students, who acclimated four different phytoplankton species to conditions mimicking those tested in the field. These experiments examined how factors such as light duration (constant vs. variable), iron availability (depleted vs. replete), and light stress influenced growth, productivity, and nitrate isotope fractionation under controlled conditions. The findings aligned closely with those from the field experiments but also revealed species-specific responses. For instance, the diatom Fragilariopsis cylindrus effectively dissipated excess light energy via non-assimilatory nitrate uptake, leading to enhanced isotope fractionation. In contrast, the haptophyte Phaeocystis antarctica exhibited greater sensitivity to light stress, likely due to differences in protein regulation associated with photosynthetic energy management.

This research provides valuable insights into the interplay between iron availability, light conditions, and phytoplankton physiology. Ongoing data analysis seeks to uncover the cellular and metabolic mechanisms underlying these responses. These findings will improve our understanding of nitrate isotope variability in the Southern Ocean and contribute to broader efforts to model marine nutrient cycles and their impact on global climate regulation.
